perturbation.original_text: (d) All Information, including any copies thereof, in any media, in the possession or control of Recipient and Information embodied or included in any software or data files loaded or stored on computers in the possession or control of Recipient, its agents or employees, shall be removed and returned to the Company upon demand, but no later than the completion of work for the Company.
perturbation.changed_text: (d) All Information, including any copies thereof, in any media, in the possession or control of Recipient and Information embodied or included in any software or data files loaded or stored on computers in the possession or control of Recipient, its agents or employees, shall be removed and returned to the Company only if the company demands this within 180 days, no later than the completion of work for the Company.
perturbation.explanation: This modification introduces a potential conflict with trade secret laws. While the original text requires the return of confidential information upon demand or completion of work, the modified text imposes a 180-day time limit on the Company's ability to demand the return of information. If the Company fails to make the demand within this timeframe, the Recipient is no longer obligated to return the information. This could jeopardize trade secret protection, as a delay in demanding the return of information could be interpreted as a waiver of rights, potentially undermining the confidentiality and trade secret status of the information under both state and federal laws.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Trade Secret Law (potentially state-specific, and the Defend Trade Secrets Act (DTSA) at the federal level)

perturbation.original_text: (g) Recipient acknowledges and agrees that the Company possesses valuable know-how, proprietary, confidential and trade secret Information that has been procured or developed by the Company at great expense and that its unauthorized disclosure would result in substantial damages to the Company that may not be adequately compensated by monetary relief. Accordingly, Recipient hereby consents to the jurisdiction of the Federal and County Courts in Essex County, New Jersey and agrees that the Company may seek temporary restraining orders against it or other extraordinary relief necessary to protect the Information.
perturbation.changed_text: (g) Recipient acknowledges and agrees that the Company possesses valuable know-how. The Recipient consents to the jurisdiction of only the County Courts in Essex County, New Jersey, and agrees that the Company may seek arbitration but will be only be awarded a maximum of $5,000 if the Recipient violates the agreement.
perturbation.explanation: This change limits the venue for dispute resolution. The original text allows the Company to seek remedies in both Federal and County Courts in Essex County, New Jersey. The modified text removes the Federal court option, restricting the Company's legal recourse solely to the County Courts. It also limits the relief to Arbitration, and sets a maximum award of $5,000, regardless of the damages actually sustained by the Company. This conflicts with the standard principles of contract law, where remedies should be commensurate with the actual damages incurred and the right to pursue legal action in multiple venues can be a right.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General contract law regarding remedies and forum selection clauses; limitations on remedies may be deemed unconscionable.

perturbation.original_text: (f) Recipient further acknowledges and agrees that all new discoveries, inventions, improvements, processes, formulae, designs, drawings, training materials, original works of authorship, photos, video tapes, electronic images, documentation, trademarks and copyrights (the "Intellectual Property"), that may be developed, conceived, or made by Recipient, alone or jointly with others during her work for the Company, shall be the exclusive property of the Company and shall be deemed a work for hire. Recipient hereby assigns and agrees to assign all Recipient's rights in any Intellectual Property to the Company. Recipient hereby grants to the Company power of attorney for the purpose of assigning all Recipient's rights in Intellectual Property to the Company for the purposes of filings, registrations and other formalities deemed necessary by the Company to prosecute, protect, perfect or exploit its ownership and interests in Intellectual Property. Recipient further agrees to execute, acknowledge and deliver any documentation, instruments, specifications or disclosures necessary to assign, prosecute, protect, perfect or exploit the Company ownership of Intellectual Property.
perturbation.changed_text: (f) Recipient further acknowledges and agrees that all new discoveries, inventions, improvements, processes, formulae, designs, drawings, training materials, original works of authorship, photos, video tapes, electronic images, documentation, trademarks and copyrights (the "Intellectual Property"), that may be developed, conceived, or made by Recipient, alone or jointly with others during her work for the Company, shall be the exclusive property of the Company, only if Kathy Whitworth agrees, and shall be deemed a work for hire. Recipient hereby assigns and agrees to assign all Recipient's rights in any Intellectual Property to the Company, only if she agrees. Recipient further agrees to execute, acknowledge and deliver any documentation, instruments, specifications or disclosures necessary to assign, prosecute, protect, perfect or exploit the Company ownership of Intellectual Property, only if Kathy Whitworth agrees. The company will assume the role of ownership if Ms. Whitworth does not wish to.
perturbation.explanation: This modification undermines the 'work for hire' doctrine. The original text states unequivocally that intellectual property developed by the Recipient during her work for the Company is the exclusive property of the Company and is considered a 'work for hire.' The modified text introduces a condition that makes it all conditional, meaning she must consent for the company to take ownership of her work. This creates ambiguity and potential unenforceability under copyright law, which requires a clear and unambiguous assignment of rights for 'work for hire' arrangements.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Copyright Law (Work for Hire doctrine - 17 U.S.C. ยง 201(b))
